bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, July 31, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302006]

div1.p: Noguchi offers his opinion about a fatal case of yellow fever occurring in West Africa and the use of the yellow fever serum and vaccine.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, July 31, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302006]
div1.p:
Thank you for sending me the copies of letters of Dr. Pettman to you
and of Dr. R. O. White to Dr. Pettman, relative a case of yellow fever, occurred
in Secondee, Gold Coast, British West Africa, during the month of April, 1923.
The case mentioned in Dr. White's letter to Dr. Pettman is interesting as he
received 20 cc. of anti-icteroides on supposedly 3rd. day of illness, but died
within 2 hours from the time of serum injection with typical black vomit and
albuminuria. It is very rare to have a black vomit within 55 hours from the
time of onset. In fact, I do not think such ever occurs. Therefore, it is
more probable that the case was more advanced than assumed, probably on the 4th.
instead of 3rd. day of disease. I scarcely can think that an injection of 20 cc.
of serum could have exerted an unfavorable influence upon the course of disease
in this case.

I also note with interest about the existence of yellow fever in the
Gold Coast as evidenced by the report of 13 cases enumerated in Dr. Pettman's
letter to you. It is also interesting that Dr. Palmer confirmed the diagnosis
of yellow fever histopathologically on the Italian who died in Secondee in May
1923.

It will be of interest to watch further development in the Gold Coast
and to follow the results obtained with serum and vaccine recently shipped there.
div1.closer: Yours sincerely, (Signed) Hideyo Noguchi (Reply to your letter dated July 10, 1923.)
